Ben Vollaard (Ph.D. RAND Graduate School) is associate professor at the Economics Department of Tilburg University. Currently, he is Academic Director of the MSc program in Economics. In 2014 and in 2023, he won the Tilburg School of Economics and Management Research Valorization Award. He is also recipient of a TiU Alumni Fund grant.

Past positions include graduate fellow at the RAND Corporation, reporter at NRC and economist at the Dutch equivalent of the Council of Economic Advisors (CPB).

His research focuses on environmental fraud. He develops and tests research designs that are designed to uncover traces of hidden, illegal behavior, in a variety of contexts. The goal is to provide causal, rather than merely suggestive, evidence of wrongdoing.

He conducts his research in close contact with (retired) practitioners within the regulated industry and inspectors who monitor the industry, while maintaining his independence as an academic. Where possible, he collects first-hand evidence of the environmental consequences of the fraud.

In recent work, he provided evidence of illegal discharges of oily substances from shipping in the North Sea and on the use of illegal small-mesh nets by bottom trawlers in the North Sea. Both projects received considerable attention from lawmakers.

Does regulation of built-in security reduce crime? Evidence from a natural experiment, The Economic Journal, 2011 (with Jan van Ours). Featured in 'Economics focus' of the Economist; findings summarized in Vox column 'Reducing the invitation to crime'.
